**AI-DAO hybrid approach**
* Get a reasonable amount of data from the founders
* Use the DAO/community to generate a large amount of analyst reports
* Train the AI on the the founder data AND analyst reports
* Compensate analysts

I think this works because it generates crowd wisdom by sourcing analysis from many members of the community. However, it is hard to parse so much data quickly. AI can then step in. In other words, this could theoretically allow for more diligence than the top investment firms and 10x speeds.
Basically the whole process can be done in the time that it takes to write 1 analyst report. because all reports are done in parallel and AI makes the decisions.
It also generates sufficient data for AI to become useful and is not onerous for the founders
i think this is a better way for community input than voting, for instance. But definitely I would like to hear other alternatives

wagmi

Not exactly. Let me try to explain it better:

1) The founder applies for funding
2) The application is distributed to analysts (DAO participants)
3) The analysts write free-from reports
4) AI decides buy/sell based off of analyst reports (with access to historical track record data)

This takes advantage of the distributed nature of DAO relative to a traditional investment firm. It parallelizes the diligence process so the number of applications the DAO can process scales proportionally the number of participants in the DAO. Also quality of investments have a positive correlation with number of participants. It also allows the DAO to have a built-in moat--a network of analysts.

Thinking about the value add and there are a few different approaches worth exploring. An obvious starting point would be to leverage the DAO community in these ways:

1. Community led marketing: leveraging all members of the DAO to announce new investments, project launches, to acquire users for betas etc. via social and WOM. Effectively marketing reach that can be leveraged at no cost. 

2. Community building: allowing projects to share open source task lists with the DAO so our members can help propel progress. With intensive help for 3-4 weeks alone, a project could progress at an unparalleled rate - this is a pull factor for projects to work with DAOs.

3. User feedback: feedback from the DAO can be shared to help with product direction, test new functionality, and identify bugs. The speed at which a project can iterate will be increased massively if a pool of members are always available.
*This thread of logic where we leverage the power of the network can extend across use cases. This is really unique to DAOs. 

4. Cross-project exposure: projects that take investment could receive a proportion of tokens in a subDAO that is tied to all of the investments made in their year of investment or in the DAO. Projects would benefit from the outcome of all projects the DAO has invested in and this should uniquely build community, collab between projects, and security.

5. Shared expertise: structuring the network of DAO members by their expertise and making this searchable should allow projects to access domain experts. This is done at YC and TechStars, and is always valuable but more traditional i.e. it wouldn’t be a unique feature a DAO can provide.

If ownership is denominated in tokens, there is a real legal case for it to simply be another form of equity. That being said, if that ownership is not publicly traded, then it will have representative power within the organization as a whole (and buying/selling aforementioned representative ownership can occur privately). 
The creation of new, deep liquid markets will get the SEC interested especially if there are statements of "performance" or "return on investment" involved.
obviously you avoid that language at all costs, but the reality is, how do you keep the community incentivized if there's no financial gain to be made?

For the investors, they put down real cash (actual companies will be made once they determine they like one by voting for one). For the ones who are operationally active, they spend their time and allocate or receive equity based upon the organizational agreement for contributors. If this is followed, a real company could be fully funded through this private arrangement and then abide by normal SEC rules if it files to go public. As long as private ownership is clearly stated and agreed upon internally, there ain't much the SEC can do. 'Murica. 😂

my lawyer had this to say to your comment 'call me when you're in jail'. This is a weirdly flawed take, i'm not sure if a lawyer gave you this lol... The SEC has deemed that DAO's are subject to the 1940's security act, and therefor subject to the federally mandated rules included in the act. Wyoming even went so far as to recognize DAO's as corporate entities. However, federal law governs all corporate entities regardless of which state they belong.
now, if you are ONLY going to accept money from accredited investors, you might be able to pull this off 🙂

Actually, it would work but it'd have to be very small. It's clearly an impractical scenario (but technically feasible for very small groups [<30 from what I've read] even without accredited investors). The SEC wouldn't look at a 30MM+ membered DAO that says it's "private" and have nothing to say. But at a small level, even a verbal agreement can be considered a contract. 

Part of the reason I'm interested in understanding the legality and feasibility of a lean and mean DAO is the implications it could have on this project (Hyperscale) and the implications it could have on simplifying/decentralizing the early development process. Imagine having an internal measurement to automatically tell the team that it's time to file XYZ based upon ABC metric and previous DAOs' experience? There's huge potential for transfer learning in something like this.
Also tell your lawyer I say hi ❤️

Yes, my lawyer brought up this edge case. The problem is that it prohibits you from advertising, which imo defeats the purpose of something like hyperscale or a dao. If you can't tell people about it, and members can't tell people about it, woof.
there are a bunch of other lame rules that kick in when you go with that <35 non accredited route, so much so that most start ups just decide not to let you into a round if you're unaccredited

it is the closest thing to what hyperscale could maybe be, the problem being that the SEC RLY needs to bless you to let it happen

so what a lot of people might not get is how constitution dao actually did it

their work around was to literally say 'your tokens mean nothing. they entitle you to nothing. one day, you might get to vote on some shit. but maybe you won't. all we know is these tokens mean literally nothing and you're giving me your money. I might give it back if we fail'
so the SEC didn't care
because in no way shape or form were those tokens representing a security
it was pretty much a charity that might give you a vote on something but might not
Why even make tokens at that point? Just make an NFT for everyone and tell them it's special and unique and they can hold onto it for whatever purpose they want.
not sure, all i know is those tokens didn't mean anything

now, as soon as you say, 'these tokens entitle you to a dividend, and we are headquartered in san francisco, and my name is XYZ' you may actually go to jail and i'm not exaggerating

because you've officially crossed over into something that resembles a security. Hence the reason most crypto people stay very very anonymous LOL
or headquarter in the bahamas, or don't invest in securities state side 😉
